Tell them what happened.  In Hurricane Bob.
He looks at his wife.  Clear in a glance they hate each o guts.  Go on, she nods.  Tell it.
Pounded twelve beach houses. Expensive ones.  To rubble.
WHAMM!
Drunk and mean.  And smarter than he is.
Now tell them.  Who let our insurance lapse.
Silence.
Took six very expensive lawyers to weasel us out of it.  An inch from bankruptcy.
She winks.
Moral of the story?  When you marry a tour guide.  Confine his authority to mixing the drinks.  Same again, dear?
And holds out her glass.  Billy looks out to sea.  Like h heard this. QUOYLE (cheerful) So.  What brings you folks up from Long Island?
A beat.  While husband and wife glare at each other.
My dining salon needs refitting. And the best custom yacht upholsterer in the Northern Hemisphere just moved here.  I was forced.  To follow.

Quoyle enters, impressed by the progress of the renovatio Windows are in, walls patched, floor sanded, lights are w Through the place into... ...the kitchen, which is in surprisingly usable shape.  A alone at a butcher block table with a set of ledgers spre her.  A large mug of tea.  A bottle of Bushmill's Irish.
You are a woman of mystery, Aunt. Mystery and surprise. AGNIS (still working) Silver Melville says you was out there.  Be nice in yer story, she's payin' for a piece of this house.
Silence.
You said upholstery.  Never said yacht uphol...
...never said not.  Ask better questions, you got a chance fer better answers.  Got my shop set up in Killick-Claw, now.
Looks up.  Sees he's dazzled by how she moves right along
Two good workers.  Mrs. Mavis Bangs is an old plow horse like m'self.  But Dawn...
She winks.
Dawn's young and on the sexy side.  You oughta drop by and say hullo.

Upstairs, in what will soon become her room.  She'll be all right.
What does that mean?
She pours some whiskey into her tea cup.
Little early in the day f...
Warren died today.  That's what that means.
Drinks the whiskey.  Stares straight in his eyes.  Sees h The honesty in...
Poor old girl.
Agnis deciding.  Whether to tell him...
I used to live with someone named Warren.  Died of cancer, after nine years together.  Dearest soul on this earth.
Quoyle shocked.  What can he say?  His empathy so naked, even Agnis has to soften her voice...
Went from the funeral, and bought that dog.  Named her Warren.  Just so I could say the name a hunnerd times a day.  Women are foolish, huh?
I never thought so.
A good moment for them.  It holds a beat.
Bunny wants to bury the dog with me.  But I told her I'd rather do it alone.
Quoyle nods.  Rises slowly.  He'd better go to her.
Some advice about the child?
Another sip.

Her naked Barbies sit in a circle watching her braid a meticulous loop out of the pa foil from chewing gum wrappers.  Quoyle enters, and sits beside her.  Watches in silence, as she works. BUNNY (not looking up) Warren died today.  She's not coming back.

You can watch.
Okay.  He looks at the Barbies.
Do I have to take my clothes off?
She looks up at him.  Straight to his eyes.
You look better with 'em on.

Quoyle driving the wagon, Dennis at his side.  Up ahead o road, two figures.  Herry holds tight to his mom's hand. pulls over, and they stop.  Wavey squints at him, against

Well.  My aunt can't bring Bunny to the daycare, she's got her shop now. But I worked it out with my boss.  So I'll be bringin' her come next week.
No reaction.
If that's all right.
Love to have her.  I'm sorry, Mr. Quoyle, about the other time. Women can be moody, you know.  And temperamental.
Now she smiles.  One-tenth power.  Still a dazzler.
Only the best ones.

Good afternoon, Dennis.  Give our respects to Beety and Marty.
He waves, will do.  She takes Herry's hand, starts off do road.  Quoyle sits and watches.
Excellent posture.

REVERSE ANGLE to ...she carries her old dog.  On a clean sheet.  Rests the gently down.  The incoming tide laps over.  The sheet bil it.  She takes a step back.

A wall of Polaroids of each child faces a map of Newfoundland with drawings of moose, caribou, and lobster Herry sits alone in a doorway, watching with big eyes as. ...Quoyle, Bunny astride his back, RAMPAGES around the pa all fours, SNORTING like a crazed boar. She watches, for a long bea leans down to Herry. WAVEY (a whisper) Go on.  Get the pig.

CLOSE on Quoyle.  He is happily washing a mountain of dis cups.
So the Newfie drills another hole in the ice, aways off from the first one.  Once again, the voice booms, NO FISH DOWN HERE!
PULL BACK to see Wavey beside him.  She's drying what he

He can't help but snort out a chuckle of his own.  Sneaks over at her, and she... ...laughs out loud.  Healthy.  Sexy, even.  But from the guesses...
Heard it before, huh?

Sometimes, passion in performance. Beats the element of surprise.
And he is lost in those eyes.  Knows it's showing.  Glanc where... ...Bunny sits in a corner.  Reading to a rapt Herry.
You guys hungry?

Is he learnin'?

Wavey?  Now are the berries ready to pick?

Want to pick my berries, do you. Should I climb right up on this sink?
And then, once more she is...

Quoyle.  Takes note.

Where Jack Buggit, Tert Card, Bil and Nutbeem are all circling around a small, roughly-made attached to its rented trailer.  They are talking to each learned tones.  A Talmudic chat.  And... ...in they come.  First through the door...

Go hire Alvin Yark to build ya a sweet little rodney.  This thing's a wallowing cockeyed bastard that'll sink in a bathtub.

The word from Sinai on Quoyle's worth.  A pity.

Out the door with a SLAMM!  Quoyle stares hopelessly afte
Don't jump off a bridge over it. Anyone can make a brainless, asinine, devastatingly revealing blunder. QUOYLE (actually means this) Thanks.
What in th' furry pit of Newfie hell. Is this!?
Holds up some sheets of paper.  Photos of the Melvilles' botterjacht.  Reads...
Hitler's Barge...?
That goes with the shipping news. Profile of a vessel in port.
What about the car accident?
That's the one I didn't do.  Mrs. Diddolate sprained her wrist.  Period.
Card still reading.
So you didn't do the one Jack told yer to do, and you did one he don't know yer did!
Silence.
Pretty mu...
This copy.  Is worse.  Than yer boat.
He looks up.  Equal parts disgust and delight.
Jack even sniffs this, he cuts you up fer lobster bait.  I've half a mind to run it.
Quoyle straightens his spine.
Run it.
Strides off for the door.  Turns back...
As for the part about you havin' half a mind?  No comment.
Out the door.  SLAMM harder than Jack's.
Quoyle stumbling toward his wagon with vacant eyes.
Headline.  Reporter Disembowels Self With Rusty Joke.

Quoyle in a carpenter's belt, climbing very carefully fro onto the roof.  His vertigo apparent as he keeps to his h knees, trying to fight the compulsion to look down.  Give it, peering from the corner of his eye down the cliff, th the sea so far below.  Not a good 1dea. Comes to the shingles.  Eases his way into a fearful crou Starts hammering.  And rehearsing.
Jack, I completely understand, I would fire me, too.
Nodding, in time to the hammer strokes.
In a heartbeat.
Hammers LOUDER, speaking in rhythm...
You give me a chance, and what happens?  I buy the wrong boat, I write the wrong story, I am the lowest form of alleged life.  In fact, your comment...
Stops.
...was an insult to the doughnut.

Hear now what the hammering had masked.  Someone is reach top of the ladder, climbing onto the roof. Bunny.  Somehow she has managed to climb while carrying a on a plate.  And an open bottle of soda.  He stares at he uncomprehending.
Egg salad and Nehi grape.
She sets them down.  Stands UP on the steep pitch. QUOYLE (shocked stupid) Baby...
They're mine but I'll share.
As the plate and bottle slip neatly OFF the roof and, aft noticeable beat, shatter softly far below.  Bunny's turn shocked.  She's contemplating going after them.
DON'T MOVE!!

Okay, that was a little loud.  It has also scared the kid her wits.  Quoyle regrets this.  Starts scooching awkward the slope, inches at a time... QUOYLE (too casual) We're gonna play Wait For Daddy. Can you play that?
She's just staring over the side.  Hypnotized by the sigh slipping toward her.  Toward the edge.
And if you don't move.  Until I get there.  Then...
Closer, reaching toward her back...
...then you win!
...GRABS her arm, she STARTLES, violently LURCHING, but h her to him.  Holds her to his heart.  Holds her.  He is b like a freight train.
That.  Was so easy.

Jack Buggit enters with energy.  Looks around.  Billy's t Nutbeem's reading.  Quoyle is cleaning out his desk, pull off his little shelf to pack away.  Goofy photo of Bunny. child-made three-legged turtle.  Tiny padded box with wha be carefully-preserved empty eggshells. Jack heads toward him.
Did ya see the Hitler's barge piece, Jocko?
I saw it.  And heard from some who'd done the same. (to Quoyle) Good.  Neatness.
Quoyle turns.  Pretty much all his possessions are in a b cardboard box.  Jack peers into it.
Reorganize.  Start over.  Good thinking.
But he's smiling.  Like he's got the point.
Thing about the barge piece?  I just thought it'd perk up th...
Got six phone calls 'bout that piece.  Six.  That'd be like half a million calls in Toronto.
Grasps Quoyle around the back of the neck.
People liked it, old son.  Crowd went down to the dock t'see the thing, but it'd already pulled out.
Quoyle stares, slack-faced into the elfin eyes...
Course you don't know anything about boats, but that's entertaining, too.  So go ahead with it.  That's the kinda stuff I want, see?
Just now, Card's jaw is scraping his boot tops.
From now on, you write a column every week.  The Shipping News.  Gonna order you a computer and everything.  And y'know the beauty part...?
Quoyle doesn't.
I don't have to tell Card all over again, cause he's already eavesdroppin'.  So I'm free to take m'leave.
Goin' fishin'?
Ah.  You've an instinct for character and idiosyncrasy, old son.
A wink.  He heads toward the door.  And never looking at
Zip yer fly, Card.

A woman looks up from her stitching.  She is solidly buil 60, Emily Dickinson hair.  A cheerful, calmly butch way a Trustworthy eyes.

Dawn, once described by Agnis as young and on the sexy si that.  Red lipstick and nails.  Her eyes float up in a wa suggests reflexive sensuality.  Agnis nods to her, and th reaches a slender pale hand...

And as she releases his hand, her eyes flick to Agnis.  S conspiracy there.  Quoyle follows his aunt back to the bi table.
I just, uh, came to see if you'd heard abou..
Silver Melville?  Snuck off in the night, they did.  Not a penny paid for all we done.
Shows him sheets of baby blue leather.
We'd installed the banquettes in her salon.  Three of the chairs done and delivered, three to go...
Points to them.  A neat row by the makeshift kitchenette.
That's.  That's just terrible.
But Agnis is thinking...
Strange.  Leavin' the chairs.
And as he glances off, he sees Dawn across the way.  Her hiked up, as if she were adjusting a stocking. She isn't wearing any.
Billowy clouds frame a languid KITE, silver and sleek, da way and that.  Graceful, in command of the currents.

ARE YOU MAKING IT DANCE WITH YOUR THOUGHTS?
On this he looks up.  Serious.
KEEP THINKING YOUR THOUGHTS! YOUR KITE IS DOING SO MUCH BETTER THAN MR. QUOYLE'S!

PULL BACK slightly to reveal that Quoyle has been sitting beside her all along.  He holds the string of a big, glum hangs motionless in space with barely a flutter.  As she the kids, he stares at her, fixedly deciding whether to a QUOYLE (barely audible) Do you think Bunny's.  Strange?

In New York.  They said she had a... personality disorder. WAVEY (softly) And it was named Petal.
Do you understand that?
All these hallucin...
The White Dog.  Sometimes with the Skinny Ghost.  Kids do things like that, it's called imagination.  Like the necklaces.

You know how many she makes?
She does.
It's a skill, she's proud of it.  And she brings her dolls along.  And she looks good in blue.  And she wears a key for a good luck charm.
Her kind smile.  No big deal.

Wavey's slow nod.
She talks to her at night.  I can hear through the door.
Very quiet now.  The wind.  The kites.

The ones I read to teach Herry. They don't make me an exp... QUOYLE (blurting) Just.  Is she okay?
That was naked.  He swallows.
I mean.  If you had to guess..

She swallows, too.  Her eyes are damp.

Hold the look.
And I don't have to guess about it.
Quoyle RUNNING, huffing, through a bog with every color o imaginable.  Around another bend in the path.  Stops.  Ha knees. Listens.  Nothing.  Shit.
IF YOU GUYS AREN'T CHASING ME, I'M GONNA BE COMPLETELY CHEESED OFF!
More nothing.  He trudges back the way he came.  Peeks ar bend to see... ...Bunny is teaching Berry to pick gooseberries.  This ti learning has started.  They are being very careful.
If you pick enough, we can sell 'em for a thousand dollars.  And give it to Aunt Agnis to make up for those Staties who didn't pay h... BUNNY (means business) Then don't.  Slow us.  Down.

Quoyle SLAPS his hands across his mouth.  Sorry!  He tipt Rounds a bend.  Walking faster now... Around another bend.  And stops.  Hold on his face.  REVE to take his view of... ...Petal, kneeling in a flimsy sundress, picking berries. Barefoot, her skirt hiked up, stained with berry juice. she turns to him... ...she is still Petal.  Her face is beautiful, and filled tender desire.  She looks at him the way he has always dr would.  He goes to... ...kneel beside her.  Touch her waist.  And now she is... ...another woman.  His hand is on Wavey's waist, and it c slowly away.  But her eyes are locked to his.  Making her WAVEY (very soft) Look.  I like you.
Even in kindness, he can smell rejection.  He starts to b but she takes his hand.  Holds it.

He nods, dumbly.  Of course.  Okay.
And friends.  Need.  To understand each other. QUOYLE (so sorry) I understand.  Believe m...
My husband drowned.  Herry was...
Hard for her.  He quiets.
He was two months old.  And Herold took the boat out.  Overnight.  To fish for haddock.
Do you understand?
Because I liked.  Haddock.
Silence.
It's four years.
She stares in his eyes.
And it's yesterday.
No smile.
Now, did I blow it.  Or can you still be my friend?
A beat.  Quoyle nods, sure.  I'll be your friend.  But wh sees is a lifetime of being Quoyle washing past his eyes. her murmur...

And from his heart...

He stands up.  HEAR him stumble off.  HOLD on her.
A grassy place above an empty sea.  The rest of the world Two figures climb the gentle hill.

Oh.

Oh, that'd be Agnis.

He hears the thread of feeling in his simple words.  And more.  Withdraws two cans of paint from his bag.  One whi black.  Two brushes.  Lays them out carefully, for this t sacred.

An easy smile.  Stating the obvious.

The old man's face just stops.  The eyes sharpen.  Into a

As if that were enough.
Hey.  If you wanna rest next to him.  I'll paint yours at the same time.  No extra trouble.
Billy stares at him.  Stares at him.  Clears his throat,
Then better get Alvin Yark. T'build yer a real boat.  So yer'll be around.

Of Bayonet Melville.
